title: Article and photograph on Juneteenth - claim

content.description:
Source 1
“The recent picnic which was held by the freedmen, last Saturday, the anniversary of the emancipation proclamation at the San Pedro Springs, was quite a grand affair, so we hear from different sources. Several hundred blacks were present on the occasion, besides a number of officers and soldiers of the army, and a few other citizens as spectators. A good deal of dancing was done by the freedmen, and a good deal...was drunk by the whole gathering, [and] some speeches were made.” 
Article in the Southern Intelligencer, a newspaper published in Austin, Texas, June 21, 1866  

Source 2Two African American Women in a Decorated Buggy Parked in Front of Antioch Baptist Church in Houston, Texas, on Juneteenth 1908
MSS0281-PH037, MSS 0281 Reverend Jack Yates Family and Antioch Baptist Church Collection 1872-1986, African American History Research Center, Houston Public Library
content.question: Which of the following claims about Juneteenth Day celebrations could best be supported by evidence from Source 1?

choices.label: Juneteenth Day celebrations were held annually in African American communities across the United States.
Juneteenth Day celebrations mark the passage of the first document to mention “absolute equality of personal rights...between former masters and slaves.”
Juneteenth Day celebrations marked the ongoing struggle by formerly enslaved individuals to achieve the economic equality they had been promised.
Juneteenth Day celebrations in African American communities often included singing spirituals, feasting, and dancing.

content.answer: Juneteenth Day celebrations in African American communities often included singing spirituals, feasting, and dancing.
